IMPORTANT: New dates for the end of non-security updates for Windows 11, version 22H2 
The new end date is June 24, 2025 for Windows 11, version 22H2 Enterprise and Education editions. Home and Pro editions of version 22H2 will receive non-security preview updates until June, 26, 2024. 
After these dates, only cumulative monthly security updates will continue for the supported editions of Windows 11, version 22H2. The initial date communicated for this change was February 27, 2024. Based on user feedback, this date has been changed so more customers can take advantage of our

This security update includes improvements that were a part of update  
KB5036980 
 (released April 23, 2024). When you install this KB: 
This update addresses an issue that might affect domain controllers (DC). NTLM authentication traffic might increase. 
This update addresses an issue that might affect Virtual Secure Mode (VSM) scenarios. They might fail. These scenarios include VPN, Windows Hello, Credential Guard, and Key Guard. 
This update addresses an issue that affects Server Message Block (SMB) clients. They fail to make  
SMB Multichannel

KB5036980 
 (April 23, 2024). In the Windows Event Log, Event ID 30826 appears for Microsoft-Windows-SMBClient/Connectivity. 
If you installed earlier updates, only the new updates contained in this package will be downloaded and installed on your device.

Windows 11 servicing stack update - 22621.3522 and 22631.3522 
This update makes quality improvements to the servicing stack, which is the component that installs Windows updates. Servicing stack updates (SSU) ensure that you have a robust and reliable servicing stack so that your devices can receive and install Microsoft updates.

summary:
KB5037771, released on May 14, 2024, is a quality update for Windows 11 version 22H2 (all editions) and version 23H2 (all editions), addressing critical issues related to VPN connectivity and performance regressions from prior updates. It specifically resolves high-impact vulnerabilities linked to NTLM authentication traffic on domain controllers and improves functions for Virtual Secure Mode and SMB Multichannel connections, particularly after the installation of KB5036980. The update includes a servicing stack update to enhance the overall update reliability, and it requires that the previous cumulative update (LCU) be installed prior to deploying this patch. Notably, this update introduces a known issue where users may encounter error code 0x80070520 when attempting to modify their profile pictures.

**Technical Breakdown**

**Vulnerabilities and Exploits**:
- This update addresses high-impact vulnerabilities including issues with NTLM authentication that may increase traffic on domain controllers and slow SMB client file transfers due to failed connections. 
- It also resolves issues with Virtual Secure Mode scenarios impacting VPN, Windows Hello, Credential Guard, and Key Guard functionalities.

**Known Issues**:
- **Profile Picture Change Failure**:
  - Symptom: Users may receive an error while changing their profile picture, leading to the error code:
    ```
    [Error Code]
    `0x80070520`
    ```
  - Workaround: A resolution is forthcoming in an upcoming update.

**Installation Process and Prerequisites**:
1. Ensure the previous cumulative update (KB5036980) is installed.
2. The update will auto-install via:
   - **Windows Update**: Automatically.
   - **Windows Update for Business**: Follows configured policies.
   - **WSUS**: Requires proper configuration:
     ```
     Product: Windows 11
     Classification: Security Updates
     ```
3. For a standalone package, access the Microsoft Update Catalog.
4. **Uninstalling the LCU**: To remove the LCU, use the following command:
   ```
   [Powershell]
   ```powershell
   DISM /online /remove-package /packagename:<LCU Package Name>
   ```
   To find the package name:
   ```
   [Powershell]
   ```powershell
   DISM /online /get-packages
   ```
   Note: Using `wusa.exe` with the `/uninstall` switch will not work due to the combined nature of the SSU and LCU. 

This summary reflects the essential technical details relevant for advanced IT administrators managing Windows 11 environments.
